Here's how to kill a nasty fly in your home. Turn off all the lights, (presuming nighttime), except the one in the bathroom. The fly will go in the bathroom. Go in with it and close the door. Observe the fly, he will fly around but soon he'll get tired and stop for a few seconds somewhere. When he stops to have a rest, stretch a rubber band with your finger and point it at him and release it. When it strikes him he'll most likely die. They're not smart enough or fast enough to dodge the rubber band. Works every time, a miss or two here and there but just reload the rubber band and wait for it to stop to rest and fire away.   Works on those nasty crickets too.  None of them live long enough to pass on to their progeny that rubber bands can kill.    Just saying'      Mike

Here’s a way to kill a fly when it’s on your window in the house.
Be very still while doing all this.
1. Wait for fly to stop flying
2. Once stopped, wait for fly to align with one of the blinds (if you have any) on the window
3. AS SOON AS THE FLY SITS STILL, PUSH THE BLIND THAT IS ALIGNED WITH THE FLY TO SMASH IT IN BETWEEN BLIND AND GLASS
4. SMOOSH! Now you have a crime scene that only needs windex to clean

I killed +-14 flies with my bare hands in the kitchen a few days ago, you just need good timing and technique.

Holding still and pouncing is a good one. Going where the fly is likely to fly away when you pounce also works well. If you're correct about the direction it will fly away, it will fly into your hands. Also, make its escape route to be to the side or even backwards. That way, it has to spin before it escapes, giving you some extra time to kill it. I usually mix those techniques and most of those pesky little bugs die.

MY LIFE HACK:
- Rather than hammering the swatter down on the fly, swing the swatter sideways, parallel to the surface the fly is on (kinda like the jump-or-duck from Wipeout)
Why does this work? Flies can choose to move away in any direction if you swat straight above them. If you swat them from the side, their only option to escape is limited to one direction: above the tip of the swatter. Works like a charm.

You are sitting at a table and a fly lands facing you. If you were to move either of your hands toward the fly it would take off in the opposite direction. But if you were to spread your hands and approach the fly from the right and left while slowly bringing your hands together, the fly's brain will be unable to decide which way to take off and will remain motionless until you cup your hands over it.

There is a way to kill a fly, there is a trick.  Use a paper towel like a large sheet size, goes slowly towards it as having a white sheet of the towel then once your close enough, just kill it.  Cheaper than having a fly smacker.  Then again, if I have to choose between a wooden back scratcher and a plastic fly swatter, I prefer a wooden back scratcher instead of a plastic fly swatter, the fact I killed tons of them not swatting them on the window or walls, I freaking hit them in the air so hard they die within an instance.  If I am forced to choose between a ruler tool and a plastic fly swatter, I prefer the ruler no matter what because I am still able to kill it with that thing.  Trust me I think there is a gimmick about these cheap plastic fly swatter, yes it is traditional we killed bugs with it but they break so easily and barely kill the fly because they get the hint of something is going kill it in front of them.  The hint reason why I go with the white paper towel sheet is that they are seeing 1 color, white and it reflects on bright things as represent of blindingness which fools the fly all the time, even you got color brown, it won't move because all they see is 1 color which they are trying think for "what is this object in front of me" that what they are thinking.

Sixty years ago my hillbilly Missouri grandmother had an outhouse that was always swarming with those greenback flies in the summer. There was this big family get together one afternoon, and the women had set out a fried chicken dinner on makeshift tables in the yard. As my mother and I were going through the line to fill our plates, she said, "Jim, now would be a good time to use that toilet, because the flies are all down here on the food." I poked her with my elbow, whispered to her to shut up, and moved ahead in the line. My family had great immune systems, and my mother had a great sense of humor.

You just gotta guess where the fly is going to go. I always realized I was about a half second too late. So I started playing around with how close a fly would let me get before it flew away. If it were just resting on a wall, the closest one would let me get was about 6 to 12 inches. I noticed if it were eating, they would let you get much closer. Some even as close as 3 inches! So that's where I came up with my striking distance. As for angle of attack, I noticed the majority of flies were taking off at about a 45° angle and flying in whatever general direction they were facing. So, I took count with how late I was with swatting the fly. Changed my striking distance. Changed my target zone to roughly one inch infront of the fly. Now I'm swatting them with 80% accuracy! Even been catching some, out of the air, with my bare hands and letting them go outside. Long story short, you just gotta "lead" them.

Easiest way to catch a fly? First get a 1-quart mason jar. Put some soapy water, about half full. Run water to produce a nice layer of suds to the top.
Wait for a fly to land on the ceiling then bring the prepared jar directly up underneath it. It’ll see it coming but flies have to drop before they can fly. So they fall into the suds and, as they struggle, get sucked down through the suds and drown in the soapy water below. Never known it to miss.

From my deep thinking
1: flies hair on their body is picking up sounds, not air movement alone. If that's the case they would be in panic all the time.
2: there eyes don't see the way we do, they see the world as static pictures. Sounds disrupt it and they see everything around them better. (Keeping still and quite would help you capture them) (2.5) they can't see far away either. they only see what sound bounces off of and it becomes harder for them the further away it is coming from.
3: They don't need light or dark because of this.
4: They fly into glass because they can't sense it. As I talked about in (2)
.. these are my ideas don't shoot me for it..
Edit--
5) they aren't processing the world 10 times faster, they can simply see our movements in such detail that they can pick up even our hearts beating. They fly away immediately when our bodies excite the air with sound from our clothes and the sound we have when swatting them.

I think I figured out their patterns.
Don't hit them straight down because they could go any direction, making this method unpredictable. If you attack straight from any side and aim ahead of that direction, they usuallt fly opposite the direction you attack from, but often fly at a random angle. This makes this method more predictable but still not good enough. If you attack from any side AND at a specific angle, they still fly the opposite direction of the attack, but they almost always follow the same angle you attack from. Therefore if you attack from the left at an upward diagonal angle, they very often fly to the right at an upward diagonal angle. In this situation, you would aim your attack ahead of them to the right at an upward diagonal angle where you predict they will fly. This way, even though they dodge almost as soon as you move, you'll catch them in their flight path. It works for me most of the time but every now and then they do something tricky.

I've gotten good at killing these guys with my bare hands. I don't need a swatter. I go at them praying mantis style with my hands outstretched and ready to "clap". I carefully approach in small jerking motions (similar to how praying mantis approach their pray) till I'm close enough to "clap" above them. They fly into it and die. It isn't fool proof and requires some patience but helpful when I see a fly in a public location where one typically doesn't have a fly swatter on hand. Most of my misses were from flys who decide to fly away on their own before I can get into position. Just have to be lucky and have the fly busy long enough for me to get setup for the kill.

Flys got quick reflexes but not much in brains. They see the motion and try to fly away but they can't really take that time to determine the optimum path to avoid the motion. (like not reacting to it or flying in a more horizontal direction). They instinctively fly up and away in nearly all cases. You just have to take advantage of that and get in low enough that you catch them in that initial "up" portion of their flight path where there is typically little variation in the direction they go in. It's the most predictable place to get the fly when they try to avoid you. ;)

Simple: You gotta beat 'em at their own game - lead the swatter out a few inches ahead of the fly. Better: (much better, when it comes to flies inside your home): Don't feed or tempt the flies. Keep anything you can't run through a garbage disposal (e.g., chicken scraps) in a zip lock bag in the freezer until it's time to take your garbage out to the street for the garbage man to pick up. And keep the outside garbage can (which shouldn't have ANY rotting food in it anyway) as far away from the house as possible. Otherwise, the flies are buzzing around it (attracted by the smell) just waiting for the opportunity to enter your house when you leave a door open for a millisecond.

By being diligent about these things, and using common sense, I NEVER have fly problems, even in the summer. (Common sense: Don't leave outside doors open any longer than necessary - kids have heard that one from their parents for ages.)

Here's a guaranteed way to kill a fly:

Take some liquid cleaner like Lysol (or even generic brand, lemon scented works best), dilute it with water in a spray bottle. Turn the nozzle to stream and spray the fly (it must be on stream, spray won't work). It stuns the fly and it falls to the floor. Keep spraying until fly can't move, then take a paper towel and throw fly away. Clean up any remaining cleaner, if it was on the wall it will dry as long as you don't spray too much. Approach the fly, slowly, with both hands a couple inches above the surface. No, vertical, like you are getting ready to clap. As you gradually move the hands closer to each other, the fly will stop all of his/her motions. You also freeze. As the fly thinks that you are nothing to worry about, you clap your hands together quickly. As you are doing this, the fly realizes that you are trouble, and will likely fly up, and slightly backwards. This should place his filthy body between your hands as they “SMACK” together.
Slapping your hand straight down, onto a hard surface, can hurt. It also allows the fly to survive if it can move about half the width of your hand. Clapping your hands slightly above the fly, allows you to bring them together much faster, and requiring a full hand width to escape. I started doing this ten years ago. It has increased my kill percentage, and starts conversation with people who ask what you are doing.

Never kill a fly on food or eating surfaces!  Water and dish soap mixture in spray bottle (six drops per 1 quart). shake vigorously. Mist spray up close or stream spray from distance on surface fly only. Spray again. Water will weigh down and prevent flight (most of time) and borax in soap will dry out innards leaving perfect dead specimen with no splattered guts. Wipe surfaces of any flies and soap residue.

My grandpa taught me a trick to get em with just your hands, though it doesn't work every time. Instead of actually trying to smack down on the fly, you veeeery slowly lower your two hands just above the fly, palms facing each other, and SLAP em together. The movement will startle the fly, causing it to fly upwards instinctually, right inbetween your hands.
Another tip: use a spray bottle with a mist nozzle. The water will build up on their wings and make them too heavy to fly, making them vulnerable to a heavy boot.

I've found the easiest and surest way to kill flies (especially the smart ones) is to use a spray bottle filled with isopropyl alcohol. The silver spray bottle sold at Home Depot works well with the nozzle set to spray a cone of alcohol. You spray them so that they either get the full cone of spray or have to fly through the cloud of alcohol mist. This starts to incapacitate them and when they're momentarily down, you can soak them. Once soaked they can be disposed of with tissue. Some flies are too smart and fast to kill with a fly swatter so I came up with this method. Isopropyl alcohol leaves no residue and there are no fly guts to clean up.

Surprised the author didn't cover what I call "radar jamming."  It's when you target a fly between your hands as it you're about to clap your hands––and you do! And kill the fly, because your hands are coming in opposite directions and the fly doesn't know which way to fly. It's brain is jammed with indecision and it gets killed.

BTW, it will let you kill it with your bare hands, if you don't mind.... you bring your hands together from bith sides, at an equal speed, and accelerate to fly-smashing speed for the last few centimeters (couple of inches, for US Americans ;-) ) ...yep, you can squich them, or damage them, about 7 out of ten times.   try it, then wash your hands, again...

One thing I have learned from experience is that when a fly is startled it has a reflexive action to jump straight up as its first response to your attack. Years ago I read an article where the author discussed working at a bait stand at a park in 1940's Pittsburgh. He and his co-workers developed the "Sweet Slap" to kill flies by hand. Keep your hands vertical, palms facing about 3"~4" apart. Slowly move into position directly above the fly by about 3". When you start to clap your hands together the fly sees the motion and takes off vertically. Right in between your palms.

This works quite well. The downside of course is that you now have a bit of fly guts on your palms. Still, worth it for the reward of killing the little pest.

I EXPERIMENTED WITH THIS TECHNIQUE TO CATCH/KILL FLIES & IT WORKS VERY WELL:

When you spot a stationary fly, simply take a single sheet of Kitchen/Paper Towel & hold it loosely in the centre, with the towel spread out in front of your palm. Hold the towel out in front of you and advance it slowly and steadily towards the fly. When you are close to it, *the fly will not detect the approaching towel visually* - because its compound eyes will see it as a uniform expanse of white & so it won’t be able to discern that it is getting closer... All insects breathe through their skin. (The ratio of surface area to volume is what limits insects's size, a fact that makes it quite difficult for science-oriented people to enjoy sci-fi movies about giant insects!)
If there was some way to stop their breathing--ah, there is a way: soap! My favorite "pesticide" for small flying insects like mosquitoes and flies is that blue glass cleaner spray, as it tends to leave very little residue. By breaking down the insect's resistance to being water repellent, the soap enters their skin, plugs up the pores, stops the breathing, and boom! The insect crashes to the floor (or to your food if you're not careful).
For hardier insects like wasps, I prepare a biodegradable liquid soap in a long distance sprayer and can (carefully) eradicate the nest and its residents. If you have kids, invite them to use their water spray guns to join in the effort; then there's less chance of you being the one who gets stung!

My tips for swatting flies:
-Make sure the fly is on a flat surface clear of any fragile or round objects
-Aim for hitting the fly with the centre or the "sweet spot" of the swatter. This way you maximise the chance of hitting once it starts flying away.
-Approach the fly slowly. I didn't know flies had trouble seeing static objects I kinda just found out moving slowly allows you to get closer without it flying away. Exercise lots of patience.
-Get as close as possible to maximise your chance of getting the fly but beware the risk of the insect flying away before you have the chance to swat it. You need some experience with this tip.
-Get behind the fly. I don't know why but I can generally get closer to a fly when I'm behind it. I thought those things had all-round vision but perhaps their rear view is not as good. You may need to rely on luck for this tip as well as for the first tip.
-Use bait. I usually sprinkle some crumbs of any left-overs onto the floor and wait for flies to let their guards down. Sometimes the squashed carcasses of previous victims make good bait too.

Using most of these tips I've even been able to squash flies under my shoe by lifting it slightly over bait. It's become somewhat of a past-time for me on some occasions. Maybe I've spent too much time killing flies.

Edit: FYI most of the time I don't use a fly swatter but a slipper

To kill a fly: Slowly position palms facing each other like 2 feet apart and then clap once as fast as possible directly above the fly. The lower edge of your hands should be an inch or less above the fly, with about 2/3 of your hand length behind the fly (they jump backwards when they first take off). Near misses can stun the fly for a second and drop it from the air, kill it quickly. When you get good at this, the only downside is squashed fly on you hands is disgusting.

Open your hands 18-24 inches apart. Slowly move your hands to be in-line with the fly, maintaining the distance between your hands. Clap swiftly. The fly will almost always take off, and fly into the path of your hands. Basically just clap directly above that pancake that the fly is on.

This technique abandons the flawed strategy of trying to be faster than the fly. It uses the reflexes of the fly against the fly. Your hands can start a little too high to hit the fly if the fly were to remain still, but the fly attempts to dodge and ends up "dodging" right into the clap.

I noticed flies tend to jump backwards during take off. So when I swat them in mid-air with my hands, I clap over them... and just behind them. If I tried to actually swat them they'd have already taken off, so the key is to know where they'll be once you make your move. In mid-air.

The trick is that the distance, both above and behind, changes based on the ambient temperature due to flies being coldblooded. It's a much greater challenge during hot summer days, you have to nail a spot a few inches in size with your hands that's nearly a foot above and behind the fly. Whereas during late summer / early fall you'll need to be just inches above him, almost grazing your hands on the surface on approach.

Im not saying anyone has to love flies or let them crawl all over your food, but I think its a little much to want to hate flies. They're really fascinating creatures, and only a small number of fly species actually bother with people. Not to mention, they're decomposers. Most of the stuff we eat is dead. When a fly lands on your hamburger, its just following its instincts to help break down dead matter and clean the earth! Without decomposers like flies, the Earth would be even more littered in garbage than it already is. Some flies are even pollinators, meaning some of our food relies on flies.

Okay, you can all hate me for defending flies now. Go ahead with your "A fly must've wrote this" comments. 😔😔 I just believe that even animals we consider "gross" can be fascinating, and of course, everything has its place in the ecosystem. I figured out how to catch them by hand a long time ago. Approach slowly from behind then when you are about as close as you can get without scaring it sweep your hand as fast as possible towards the fly, curving upwards in relation to the surface on which it is resting as you approach its location. Clap about 2 inches above the fly from a horizontal surface and you stand a 60-80 percent chance of nailing it. This works because flies need to jump up before flying forward. Good luck in helping these little guys.

Fun fact if you want to kill flies with your hands.

Slowly move your hands close to the fly. Hold your hands apart from each other about a foot from each other and hold them about 2"-3" above where the fly is (fly in the middle of the foot gap). Clap your hands together as fast as you can and you'll likely kill it in your hands. This trick has worked for me pretty much 90% of the time.

This is no house fly, this is a type of fly that dwells around animal waste, e.g. rotten foods, but does hang around picnics, barbeques, fruits, etc., notice the green body? House flies prefer foods inside and around the house. Although it is less as filthy as the green bodied fly. But those larger flies and the ones with a neddle type proboscis to suck blood (horsefly), like that of mosquitos, are a serious problems. They insert it into and animal to suck blood and they sting as they do, including the devils that bite while on the beach. Some are even hard to swat. One swat on a housefly and its dead. One swat on a horsefly and it still flies off. But, one swat to a beach fly, it flies off then returns a few minutes later. That's how hungry they are. Catch one and see how empty its body is. That's why you can't kill them on the first, second or third swat. I used to catch and train them as acrobatics.

Another trick that helps swat the fly. Its not very smart. You are. You can predict where its goin to fly and its very predictable. Hit just in front of it, becouse as you will begin to swat the fly it will immediately lift off, but it will instinctively going to fly straight as it is the fastest route to escape. However, you knew that and as the fly is moving forward, its only going towards the spot where you were aiming anyway.
